Headline.Para: MyTurf; Children hooked by a pastime of old - longkang fishing

LeadPara.Para: My Turf is a fortnightly series that aims to share untold stories of our neighbourhoods. In this instalment, we take a look at longkang fishing.
Older Singaporeans may have fond memories of catching small fish in a nearby longkang (the Malay word for drain), back when the island was far less developed.

TailParas.Para: It's still possible to indulge in the pastime here - albeit in a modern, man-made pond - giving children a taste of how their parents and grandparents grew up.

There are five longkang fishing facilities licensed to operate in Singapore, located in Bugis, Lim Chu Kang, Pasir Ris and Yishun, according to the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore, which issues them with animal exhibition licences.
Each consists of ponds or streams with water between ankle-and shin-deep, where youngsters can try to catch small fish in nets.
One is even based in a shopping mall. Fish @ Bugis+ has been operating at an open-air area on the seventh floor of the mall for 2Â½ years.

Manager Yun Ai Ling, 66, allows only children under 12 in the water and is busiest on weekends: "On an average Saturday, we get about 20 to 30 children. They are usually accompanied by their parents or maids."
Some children will use their hands to splash the water or grab the fish but Ms Yun said: "When we spot them doing that, we have to stop them."

Orto's general manager Samuel Liu, 36, said his Lorong Chencharu longkang adopts measures to provide a clean and safe environment for children.
His longkang fishing pond is open only on weekends, public holidays and school holidays.
"Whenever we are not using it (the pond), we will drain it and clean it; if not, algae may grow and it will become slippery."
Families with their children longkang fishing at Orto, Lorong Chencaru. ST PHOTO: KHALID BABA
For regular business on Saturdays and Sundays, staff top up the water and release the fish on Friday night, and empty it on Monday morning.
Mr Liu has noticed that some children adopt their own fishing tactics and decide to work as a team - even though they have only just met each other for the first time.
"Someone will chase the fish in one direction, while another will catch it. And then they switch roles," he explained.
Ms Yun is driven by nostalgia, and the Bugis+ shopping mall is a world away from the Hougang kampung where she grew up and went longkang fishing with her siblings.
"When I was around seven or eight years old, we would go to streams all the time to catch fish like this. It was free, and I found it a lot of fun to catch the fish and keep them as pets at home."
A spokesman for national water agency PUB said there are certain areas at reservoirs and selected waterways where fishing is permitted, though it is illegal to enter the water.
"PUB will take action against those who enter the waterways without prior approval, and those caught may be fined up to $3,000."

Rules were the last thing on Mr Derrick Ho's mind when he fished in longkangs as a child. "In the past, nobody cared," said the 34-year-old, who works in sales. "We just went into the canals and used our hands to catch the fish."
Fish in a tank caught by children from a childcare at a longkang pond in Fish@Bugis+. PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

As to whether a man-made facility matches up to the "real thing", Mr Ho said it is easier to catch the fish due to the limited space for them to swim about. "But it is also safer as the water level remains constant and won't rise suddenly."
The PUB spokesman pointed out that in canals, heavy rainfall upstream will cause water to flow in quickly. Hence, there are railings and warning signs to deter people from entering.

Ms Lim Pei Wen, 32, a private tutor, said that taking her 21-month-old son Kenji Neo longkang fishing can help develop his sensory and motor skills."It is a good experience for kids. As they use the net to catch the fish, it can improve their hand-eye coordination," she said.

Five-year-old Linus Sun visited Fish @ Bugis+ on an excursion with his childcare centre Little Wonders Montessori Childcare and, after getting to grips with his net and managing to catch some fish, he said he hoped to keep them "as pets".
Pointing to his shin, another child from the centre, Samuel Teo, four, said: "The water was until here. I don't know how to swim, but I was brave."

Article.Art: Orto in Lorong Chencharu is one of five longkang fishing facilities licensed to operate in Singapore. Each of these facilities features ponds or streams with water between ankle- and shin-deep, where youngsters can try to catch small fish using small nets.
